availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Benjamin F. Buckner (Clark County, Kentucky, attorney and soldier.)

body.p: Clark County, Kentucky, attorney and soldier. Illinois native. Son of Aylett Hawes Buckner and Charlotte F. Buckner. Married to Helen B. Martin Buckner in Clark County, Kentucky, on March 5, 1863. Student in Clark County in 1850. Household owned three enslaved persons in Clark County in 1850. Attorney in Clark County in 1860. Household owned three enslaved persons in Clark County in 1860. Served in the 20th Kentucky Volunteer Infantry Regiment (U.S.A.) as major from January 6, 1862, to April 17, 1863. Resigned from U.S. military service on April 17, 1863.

Patrick A. Lewis, "'All Men of Decency Ought to Quit the Army': Benjamin F. Buckner, Manhood, and Proslavery Unionism in Kentucky," The Register of the Kentucky Historical Society vol. 107, no 4 (Autumn 2009): pp. 513-549.
